articles.headline: Revealing Hidden Costs of Your 401(k)
articles.snippet: Administrative fees in many retirement plans can be substantial, and they aren’t always levied equitably.
articles.abstract: Administrative fees in many retirement plans can be substantial, and they aren’t always levied equitably.
articles.lead_paragraph: Your 401(k), 403(b) or other similar plan isn’t free. In fact, it’s probably pretty expensive, costing you tens of thousands of dollars in lost retirement money over the course of your career.

articles.headline: Airlines, Now Flush, Fear a Downturn
articles.snippet: Despite rising fares and multiple fees, carriers have managed to keep their planes full. But there are signs the situation may cool after a hot summer vacation season.
articles.abstract: Despite rising fares and multiple fees, carriers have managed to keep their planes full. But there are signs the situation may cool after a hot summer vacation season.
articles.lead_paragraph: So far this year, the airlines have been able to repeatedly raise ticket prices while still filling their planes. It has been a lucrative formula.

articles.headline: Blunt U.S. Warning Reveals Deep Strains in NATO
articles.snippet: The warning by Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates came amid growing U.S. resentment against NATO over the air war in Libya.
articles.abstract: The warning by Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates came amid growing U.S. resentment against NATO over the air war in Libya.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates sharply criticized NATO nations on Friday for what he said were shortages of military spending and political will, warning of “a dim if not dismal future” and “irrelevance” for the alliance unless more member nations contributed weapons, money and personnel.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: Now Lobbying for a Poor Indian State
articles.snippet: Amit Mitra, whose party defeated a communist coalition, is the point man for one of India’s biggest economic challenges.
articles.abstract: Amit Mitra, whose party defeated a communist coalition, is the point man for one of India’s biggest economic challenges.
articles.lead_paragraph: KOLKATA, India — Amit Mitra was recently telling visitors why he had just left his cushy job as corporate India’s top lobbyist to brave the tumultuous politics of his home state, West Bengal, by becoming its finance minister. A colleague barged into his office.

articles.headline: Truck Dealers Win $2 Billion in Ford Suit
articles.snippet: Commercial truck dealers for Ford sued the company, claiming it had violated agreements on sales prices, and won.
articles.abstract: Commercial truck dealers for Ford sued the company, claiming it had violated agreements on sales prices, and won.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The Ford Motor Company must pay $2 billion in a class-action lawsuit accusing it of overcharging commercial truck dealerships over an 11-year period, an Ohio judge ruled on Friday.

articles.headline: The Poster Plant of Health Food Can Pack Disease Risks
articles.snippet: As a horrified Europe learned over the past month, sprouts are a high-risk food for carrying harmful bacteria like salmonella or the toxic forms of E. coli, according to experts.
articles.abstract: As a horrified Europe learned over the past month, sprouts are a high-risk food for carrying harmful bacteria like salmonella or the toxic forms of E. coli, according to experts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sprouts are a fixture of salad bars and the epitome of health food to many people. But the reality can be very different.

articles.headline: Opposition Is Split on How to Reshape Yemen
articles.snippet: Some say the path forward must include radical changes and others are urging a more moderate political resolution endorsed by the United States and Yemen’s Arab neighbors.
articles.abstract: Some say the path forward must include radical changes and others are urging a more moderate political resolution endorsed by the United States and Yemen’s Arab neighbors.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — The protesters, arrayed in the tens of thousands under a blazing sun, pumped their fists in unison as they stood on the hot tarmac on Friday and chanted triumphantly, “The people, at last, have defeated the regime!”

articles.headline: Computer Studies Made Cool, on Film and Now on Campus
articles.snippet: Educators and technologists say films like “The Social Network” and celebrity entrepreneurs are inspiring more students to earn computer science degrees.
articles.abstract: Educators and technologists say films like “The Social Network” and celebrity entrepreneurs are inspiring more students to earn computer science degrees.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — When Keila Fong arrived at Yale, she had never given much thought to computer science. But then last year everyone on campus started talking about the film “The Social Network,” and she began to imagine herself building something and starting a business that maybe, just maybe, could become the next Facebook.

articles.headline: Deutsche Bank’s Chief Casts Long Shadow in Europe
articles.snippet: Josef Ackermann, chief executive of Europe’s largest bank, emerged from the 2008 financial crisis with deep influence on the Continent’s financial future.
articles.abstract: Josef Ackermann, chief executive of Europe’s largest bank, emerged from the 2008 financial crisis with deep influence on the Continent’s financial future.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: Can Ticketmaster’s Builder Now Unseat It?
articles.snippet: Fred Rosen, the man who made Ticketmaster ubiquitous, wants to put ticketing back in the hands of venues.
articles.abstract: Fred Rosen, the man who made Ticketmaster ubiquitous, wants to put ticketing back in the hands of venues.
articles.lead_paragraph: FREDRIC D. ROSEN has winked through Steely Dan, blinked through Neil Diamond and nodded through the Rolling Stones.

articles.headline: Somalis Kill Mastermind of 2 U.S. Embassy Bombings
articles.snippet: Fazul Abdullah Mohammed, the mastermind of the embassy bombings in Kenya and Tanzania, was killed in a shootout in Mogadishu.
articles.abstract: Fazul Abdullah Mohammed, the mastermind of the embassy bombings in Kenya and Tanzania, was killed in a shootout in Mogadishu.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Fazul Abdullah Mohammed, Al Qaeda’s leader in East Africa and the mastermind of the American Embassy bombings in Kenya and Tanzania, was killed in a late-night shootout at a security checkpoint in Mogadishu, Somalia’s capital, Somali and American officials said Saturday.

articles.headline: When Two-Thirds Isn’t Enough
articles.snippet: It’s one of the great anomalies of our ownership society: shareholders own companies, but executives can easily slap them down. A company in Ohio learned this the hard way.
articles.abstract: It’s one of the great anomalies of our ownership society: shareholders own companies, but executives can easily slap them down. A company in Ohio learned this the hard way.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT’S one of the great anomalies of our ownership society: shareholders own companies, but executives can easily slap them down. The hired help, in other words, holds the cards.

articles.headline: For the Executive With Everything, a $230,000 Dog to Protect It
articles.snippet: A growing number of wealthy people around the world are coveting the security — and status — provided by a dog with the right credentials.
articles.abstract: A growing number of wealthy people around the world are coveting the security — and status — provided by a dog with the right credentials.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Don’t call her a guard dog.

articles.headline: Too Big to Fail, or Too Trifling for Oversight?
articles.snippet: Companies concerned with stricter oversight that could erode profits have been lobbying financial regulators to avoid being designated “systemically important.”
articles.abstract: Companies concerned with stricter oversight that could erode profits have been lobbying financial regulators to avoid being designated “systemically important.”
articles.lead_paragraph: It is not very often that business people head to Washington to explain how unimportant they are.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Afghan Taliban Cede Ground in the South, but Fears Linger
articles.snippet: President Obama confronts a mixed landscape of improvement and uncertainty in Afghanistan as he weighs how many troops to withdraw this summer.
articles.abstract: President Obama confronts a mixed landscape of improvement and uncertainty in Afghanistan as he weighs how many troops to withdraw this summer.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARJA, Afghanistan — The poppy harvest is over and the fighting season has arrived in southern Afghanistan — except this year the Taliban have not returned in their usual numbers to intensify the war, Afghans across the region say.

articles.headline: U.S. Underwrites Internet Detour Around Censors
articles.snippet: The Obama administration is leading a global effort to deploy “shadow” Internet and mobile phone systems that dissidents can use to undermine repressive governments.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration is leading a global effort to deploy “shadow” Internet and mobile phone systems that dissidents can use to undermine repressive governments.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration is leading a global effort to deploy “shadow” Internet and mobile phone systems that dissidents can use to undermine repressive governments that seek to silence them by censoring or shutting down telecommunications networks.
articles.byline: By James Glanz and John Markoff

articles.headline: Syrian Troops Retake Control of Rebellious Town in North
articles.snippet: Backed by tanks and helicopter gunships, government forces smashed what remained of an armed uprising in Jisr al-Shoughour, after residents fled into neighboring Turkey.
articles.abstract: Backed by tanks and helicopter gunships, government forces smashed what remained of an armed uprising in Jisr al-Shoughour, after residents fled into neighboring Turkey.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Syria’s most trusted forces retook control of a rebellious northern Syrian town on Sunday, responding with tanks and helicopter gunships and crushing an alliance of mutinous soldiers and armed civilians, while prompting thousands of frightened residents to flee into Turkey or camp out in open fields on the border.

articles.headline: Same Gaffes, but Now on Twitter
articles.snippet: Sarah Palin’s e-mails and Anthony Weiner’s Twitter exchanges are a logical next step in the evolving relationship of politics and media technologies.
articles.abstract: Sarah Palin’s e-mails and Anthony Weiner’s Twitter exchanges are a logical next step in the evolving relationship of politics and media technologies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Richard Nixon did some terrible things in order to maintain a grip on the Oval Office, but the dumbest may have been recording what went on there.

articles.headline: In Greece, Some See a New Lehman
articles.snippet: Some warn that a Greek restructuring would set off investor panic, as Lehman Brothers’ bankruptcy did in 2008, while others say banks and other institutions can bear any potential losses.
articles.abstract: Some warn that a Greek restructuring would set off investor panic, as Lehman Brothers’ bankruptcy did in 2008, while others say banks and other institutions can bear any potential losses.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Bond traders and officials at the European Central Bank have been unified in their warnings that a restructuring of Greece’s debt would set off an investor panic similar to the one that followed the bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers.

articles.headline: For Instant Ratings, Interviews With a Checkbook
articles.snippet: TV networks are increasingly in the news for their willingness to pay for exclusive access to news subjects.
articles.abstract: TV networks are increasingly in the news for their willingness to pay for exclusive access to news subjects.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before the subjects of headlining news stories agree to a television interview these days, some have one question: how much money can I make?
articles.byline: By Brian Stelter and Bill Carter

articles.headline: At Qualcomm, Rise of Founder’s Son Defies Hazards of Succession
articles.snippet: The chief of Qualcomm envisions a connected world where mobile devices turn on the lights, control thermostats and even diagnose illnesses.
articles.abstract: The chief of Qualcomm envisions a connected world where mobile devices turn on the lights, control thermostats and even diagnose illnesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — When Paul E. Jacobs took over from his father as chief executive of the chip maker Qualcomm in 2005, mobile phones were just beginning their transition from tools for talking to hand-held computers delivering data and entertainment.

articles.headline: Shedding Hazy Light on a Midnight Ride
articles.snippet: Sarah Palin’s recent description of Paul Revere’s legendary ride caused a debate, and rival versions of the event, on Wikipedia.
articles.abstract: Sarah Palin’s recent description of Paul Revere’s legendary ride caused a debate, and rival versions of the event, on Wikipedia.
articles.lead_paragraph: The potential presidential candidate Sarah Palin has been criticized for her recent description of Paul Revere as “he who warned the British that they weren’t going to be taking away our arms, by ringing those bells.”

articles.headline: Debt Collectors Ask to Be Paid a Little Respect
articles.snippet: Debt collectors are well aware that they are not a sympathetic lot, but the industry trade association has begun a charm offensive.
articles.abstract: Debt collectors are well aware that they are not a sympathetic lot, but the industry trade association has begun a charm offensive.
articles.lead_paragraph: EDINA, Minn. — As a longtime debt collector, Lesllie Rogers has been routinely insulted, pummeled with obscenities, crudely propositioned and threatened with violence by the people she calls.

articles.headline: Obama Seeks to Win Back Wall St. Cash
articles.snippet: President Obama has started an aggressive push to win back the allegiance of a vital source of campaign cash in 2008.
articles.abstract: President Obama has started an aggressive push to win back the allegiance of a vital source of campaign cash in 2008.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A few weeks before announcing his re-election campaign, President Obama convened two dozen Wall Street executives, many of them longtime donors, in the White House’s Blue Room.

articles.headline: Two States Ask if Paperwork in Mortgage Bundling Was Complete
articles.snippet: The attorneys general of New York and Delaware are looking into whether the documentation on bundled mortgages was proper and complete.
articles.abstract: The attorneys general of New York and Delaware are looking into whether the documentation on bundled mortgages was proper and complete.
articles.lead_paragraph: Opening a new line of inquiry into the problems that have beset the mortgage loan process, two state attorneys general are investigating Wall Street’s bundling of these loans into securities to determine whether they were properly documented and valid.

articles.headline: In Nuclear Crisis, Crippling Mistrust
articles.snippet: A look at the first days after a tsunami crippled Japan’s Fukushima Daiichi plant reveals that the prime minister was dangerously ill informed.
articles.abstract: A look at the first days after a tsunami crippled Japan’s Fukushima Daiichi plant reveals that the prime minister was dangerously ill informed.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — On the evening of March 12, the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant’s oldest reactor had suffered a hydrogen explosion and risked a complete meltdown. Prime Minister Naoto Kan asked aides to weigh the risks of injecting seawater into the reactor to cool it down.
articles.byline: By Norimitsu Onishi and Martin Fackler

articles.headline: F.B.I. Agents Get Leeway to Push Privacy Bounds
articles.snippet: The F.B.I. plans to issue a new edition of its manual giving agents more leeway to search databases, go through household trash or use surveillance teams to scrutinize people.
articles.abstract: The F.B.I. plans to issue a new edition of its manual giving agents more leeway to search databases, go through household trash or use surveillance teams to scrutinize people.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Bureau of Investigation is giving significant new powers to its roughly 14,000 agents, allowing them more leeway to search databases, go through household trash or use surveillance teams to scrutinize the lives of people who have attracted their attention.
